parameters.content:
> **About üìù**
- Runs automatically every **2 minutes**.
- Acts as the "heartbeat" of the workflow.
- You can change the interval to any value (e.g., seconds, minutes, hours, days).
- Useful when you want continuous monitoring without manual input.
The workflow checks your website every **2 minutes** (interval configurable).  
- If the website is **down (503, bad response, or error)** ‚Üí it sends an email alert and updates the GitHub-hosted status page to show **Down**.  
- If the website is **up (200)** ‚Üí it updates the GitHub-hosted status page to show **Up**.  
- The email notification includes an **HTML-formatted alert page**.  
- You can use GitHub Pages to **host the status page** publicly.

> **HTML Request & Switch üìù**
- Pings the target website (ex:(`https://app.yourdomain.com/health`).
- Returns the **status code** and full response.
- If website responds with **200**, site is considered **Up**.
- If request fails (e.g., 503, ERR_BAD_RESPONSE), it will be treated as **Down**.
- Always outputs data (even on error), ensuring the workflow doesn‚Äôt break.
Here, upload your Website URL. EX: (`https://app.yourdomain.cc/health`)

> **Email üìù**
- Sends an **email alert** if the site is down.
- Recipient: `example@gmail.com` (replace with your email/team DL).
- Subject: "Server Down".
- Message: Pre-styled HTML alert page with error details.
- Can be customized for different recipients or notification styles.

Upload with your Email ID.
EX:
examaple@gmail.com

> **Extract from File(Github)üìù**

-Extract the file from the Github Repository if the status is same (Extracted Status = Github Status) then make no changes/ no commit into Github.
-If both are no same then commit the status in the Github.

-Upload your GitHub Repository owner URL.
-Upload your Repository Name.

> **Template HTML Code & GitHub üìù**
- Dynamically creates the **status page HTML (index.html) from the existing template**.
- Two modes:
  - **Up** ‚Üí Green status page with "Server Up".
  - **Down** ‚Üí Red status page with error details (status code + error message).
- You can fully customize the HTML & CSS here for branding.
 - Commits the newly generated `index.html` file to your GitHub repo.
- Path: `index.html` in repository (default branch).
- Commit message is configurable (default: "test").
- If GitHub Pages is enabled, this file becomes the **live status page**.

parameters.content:
# üñ•Ô∏è Automated Website Uptime Monitor with Email Alerts & GitHub Status Page Update  

This n8n workflow continuously monitors your website‚Äôs availability, sends **email alerts** when the server goes down, and automatically updates a **status page (index.html)** in your GitHub repository to reflect the live status.  

---

## üìå Good to Know  
- The workflow checks your website every **2 minutes** (interval configurable).  
- If the website is **down (503, bad response, or error)** ‚Üí it sends an email alert and updates the GitHub-hosted status page to show **Down**.  
- If the website is **up (200)** ‚Üí it updates the GitHub-hosted status page to show **Up**.  
- The email notification includes an **HTML-formatted alert page**.  
- You can use GitHub Pages to **host the status page** publicly.

### ‚ÑπÔ∏è What is GitHub Pages?  
- GitHub Pages is a free hosting service provided by GitHub that lets you publish **static websites (HTML, CSS, JS)** directly from a GitHub repository.  
- You can use it to make your `index.html` status page publicly accessible with a URL like:    


### ‚ö° How to Set Up GitHub Pages for Your Status Page  
1. Create a **new repository** on GitHub (recommended name: `status`).  
2. Add a blank `index.html` file (n8n workflow will later update this file).  
3. Go to your repository ‚Üí **Settings** ‚Üí **Pages**.  
4. Under **Source**, select the branch (`main` or `master`) and folder (`/root`).  
5. Save changes.  
6. Your status page will now be live at: `https://<USERNAME>.github.io/status`


## ‚úÖ Prerequisites  
- An **n8n instance** (self-hosted or cloud).  
- A **GitHub account & repository** (to host the status page).  
- A **Gmail account** (or any email service supported by n8n ‚Äì example uses Gmail).  
- Access to the target **website URL** you want to monitor.  

---

## ‚öôÔ∏è How it Works  
1. **Schedule Trigger** ‚Üí Runs every 2 minutes.  
2. **HTTP Request** ‚Üí Pings your website URL.  
3. **Switch Node** ‚Üí Evaluates the response status (200 OK vs error/503).  
4. **Code Node** ‚Üí Generates a dynamic **HTML status page** (Up/Down).
5. **GitHub Repo & File** ‚Üí Github Repo Name Should be `https://github.com/<OWNER_NAME>/status` (recommended) & Must have(required) a blank file named as `index.html` before triggering this flow.
5. **GitHub Node** ‚Üí Updates/commits the `index.html` file in your repository.  
6. **Gmail Node** ‚Üí Sends an email alert if the site is down.  

---

## üöÄ How to Use  
1. Import the workflow JSON into your **n8n instance**.  
2. Configure credentials for:  
   - **GitHub** (Personal Access Token with repo permissions).  
   - **Gmail** (or your preferred email service).  
3. Replace the following:  
   - `https://app.yourdomain.com/health` ‚Üí with your own website URL.  
   - `example@gmail.com` ‚Üí with your email address (or distribution list).  
   - GitHub repo details ‚Üí with your repository where `index.html` will live.  
4. Deploy the workflow.  
5. (Optional) Enable **GitHub Pages** on your repo to serve `index.html` as a live status page.  

---

## üõ† Requirements  
- n8n v1.0+  
- GitHub personal access token  
- Gmail API credentials (or SMTP/email service of your choice)  

---

## üé® Customising this Workflow  
- **Interval** ‚Üí Change schedule from 2 minutes to any desired frequency.  
- **Email Content** ‚Üí Modify HTML alert template in the Gmail node.  
- **Status Page Styling** ‚Üí Edit the HTML/CSS in the Code node to match your branding.  
- **Error Handling** ‚Üí Extend Switch node for other status codes (e.g., 404, 500).  
- **Multiple Websites** ‚Üí Duplicate HTTP Request + Switch nodes for multiple URLs.  

---

## üë§ Who Can Use It?  
- **DevOps & SRE Engineers** ‚Üí For automated uptime monitoring.  
- **Freelancers/Developers** ‚Üí To monitor client websites.  
- **Startups & SMEs** ‚Üí For a free, lightweight status page without paid tools.  
- **Educators/Students** ‚Üí As a hands-on learning project with n8n.  

---

## üåü Key Features  
- üîÑ Automated uptime checks (configurable interval).  
- üìß Email notifications on downtime.  
- üìù Dynamic HTML status page generation.  
- üåç GitHub Pages integration for public visibility.  
- ‚ö° Lightweight & cost-effective (no paid monitoring tool needed).  

---

## üîó Tools Integration  
- **n8n** ‚Äì Orchestration & automation.  
- **GitHub** ‚Äì Version control + hosting of status page.  
- **Gmail** ‚Äì Email notifications.  
- **HTTP Request** ‚Äì Website availability check.  

---

## üìà Example Use Cases  
- Personal website monitoring with public status page.  
- Monitoring SaaS apps & notifying support teams.  
- Internal company services uptime dashboard.
